description.narrative: Att möta efterfrågan på elektricitet för att stödja den ekonomiska och sociala utvecklingen i Moçambique.
To support economic and social development in Mozambique through meeting the demand of electricity.

The main objective of the intervention was to extend the national electricity grid in Cuamba, Niassa province and rehabilitate the existing services, thereby provide adequate supply of electricity to support the growth of local industries, promote local trade and employment opportunities as well as social welfare for the population in the area through electrification of health and educational facilities.

sector.narrative: Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)

tag.narrative: 7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

description.narrative: There are two contributions connected to the same agreement; “Support to Rural Electrification in Niassa Province, in Mechanhelas, Metarica, Maua and Marrupa districts”. This is the second contribution/second phase to the specific agreement. This second phase is called “Cuamba Rural Electrification” (51140038), and was agreed on 3 December 2012 (Amendment 8 to the specific agreement) and available in TRAC. The first phase (23000175) was monitored through the previous PLUS-system, and is not in TRACT. It has therefore been handled separately (see Completion Memo “Niassa Rural Electrification” from 2019-01-03). Both contributions are registered in PlanIt. The project was also supported by Norway through an agreement on delegated funds from Norway to Sweden. Total support (grant) to the project was SEK 106,100 000, and NOK 41,000,000. Of these funds SEK 48,100,100 was granted to the Cuamba extension (51140038). The Norwegian part of the support was closed in 2013, and has not been used for financing of the Cuamba extension (this second phase). Examples of the results that have been achieved, both expected and unexpected - the expected results were achieved, which mainly can be referred to construction and rehabilitation of electrical infrastructure (medium and low voltage distribution lines as to connect new clients). The assessed number of new connections have been made (app. 2600 connections), and 8 health centres and 6 schools in the Cuamba area are reported to have been electrified. The demand has more than doubled since 2013, which is a larger increase than expected (see further below). Sweden has not carried out any evaluation of the support, but has during the implementation financed the support of a Client Representative to the implementing organisation EDM, and a Monitoring Consultant (see further below). However, an impact assessment was financed by Norway in 2013, including all projects financed by Norway (and partly also by Sweden) in Niassa. The following main conclusions where made; • While there is evidence that wealthier households are disproportionately benefiting from the intervention (as would be expected), it was found that a high percentage of low income households have also connected and are thus benefitting from the program.• Regarding incomes, there is evidence that electrification of existing businesses has likely improved profits and productivity, increasing the general income level in the region. However, this is moderated by the very limited impact on generation of new productive activities.• Electrification has resulted in a transformation in household lighting and appliance use, but has virtually no effect on cooking, with 100% of electrified households surveyed still using charcoal or wood. On the other hand, the majority of surveyed electrified households have bought lighting (98%), mobile phones (77%), TVs (75%) and radios (53%), representing tangible quality of life improvements.• Communities have reported upon, and emphasised the importance of, the substantial communal benefits of electricity, stemming from improved security, health, education and social services. (“Impact Assessment of Rural Electrification”, Norad, October 2013) As there is no baseline with regards to share of public institutions that was connected prior to the project, it is difficult to assess the effect on public services. However, the street light added by the project is assessed to have improved the security situation in the area, and the optical fibre that has been added to the network is assessed as very positive for the facilitation of communication through internet and cell phones.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
